Amazon plans to open 100 new Whole Foods stores in the coming years.

summary: Automating Biology (22 minute read) Biology is wildly complex, and our understanding of biological systems is just scratching the surface. Automating biology will require significant investment to achieve exit velocity. These developments will pave the way for novel therapeutics that will improve health and longevity, boost biomanufacturing, and more.

summary: One Human + One Agent = One Browser From Scratch (2 minute read) one-agent-one-browser is a web browser built in three days with a single Codex CLI agent. title: Friction by Design
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-28, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcarlbarenbrug.com%2Ffriction%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/0100019c04b7a113-e659f988-67fd-417c-a0fa-0a690cdf875b-000000/3ZMQfL_8QdRvSrT5d2Syn-h_ede81FHVQ6PfhIdG4aY=442
summary: Friction by Design (2 minute read) Frictionless digital design optimizes for speed and efficiency, but removing all obstacles can eliminate awareness and meaningful decision-making. Deliberately designed friction—like confirmation pauses or undo delays—create moments of attention that respect human judgment rather than pushing machine-speed interactions. Good friction is intentional and purposeful, while bad friction wastes time without delivering value.

title: 1TB Model on a Single H200
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-28, Reading time: 31 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flmsys.org%2Fblog%2F2026-01-26-int4-qat%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019c04f90d36-f38d399c-9849-48a7-b5e2-aec41a877b4a-000000/gfjGQWSdA_jeeZYm0quvvf7mrVGKN45ydX_o2DmuTv8=442

title: Kimi Agent SDK

summary: Kimi Agent SDK (GitHub Repo) The Kimi Agent SDK is a set of multi-language libraries that expose the Kimi Code agent runtime in applications. It can be used to build products, automations, and custom tooling. The SDK clients reuse the same Kimi CLI configuration, tools, and MCP servers to stream responses in real-time, surface approvals and tool calls, and let users orchestrate sessions programmatically. Go, Node.js, and Python are supported.

title: DeepSeek-OCR 2
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-28, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fdeepseek-ai%2FDeepSeek-OCR-2%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019c04f90d36-f38d399c-9849-48a7-b5e2-aec41a877b4a-000000/jHXm0BXFqLFrxr6IOq7VYnG-FlZY-1LX0bfnlrRHnZc=442
summary: DeepSeek-OCR 2 (GitHub Repo) DeepSeek-OCR 2 is a significant upgrade to DeepSeek-OCR. It maintains high visual token compression while achieving meaningful performance improvements. The model is powered by DeepEncoder V2, which implicitly distills causal understanding of the visual world through the integration of both bidirectional and causal attention mechanisms. This leads to causal reasoning capabilities in the vision encoder and marked lifts in visual reading logic.

summary: The 80% Problem in Agentic Coding (20 minute read) AI writing most of the code places a disproportionate emphasis on the human's role of owning outcomes, maintaining quality bars, and ensuring that tests actually validate behavior. Bad processes will result in accumulated debt at an unprecedented speed.

summary: AI assisted interviews (2 minute read) When faced with a problem, strong candidates stay calm, form precise hypotheses, and then systematically test one hypothesis at a time until they zero in on a solution. AI just accelerates this process. Weak candidates blindly try things, hoping something sticks. Their process remains sloppy when using AI. AI doesn't by default make people perform better, it amplifies people's existing patterns.

title: There are 3 kinds of “going viral”, but only 1 helps your business
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-29, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fvincent-angelo-coach_there-are-3-kinds-of-going-viral-only-activity-7422300676745142272-DtWC%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019c09a55f65-66556441-e676-4ba5-a7fc-8d080f891f8d-000000/iy75ffPk4vfeN3f6Wk4nlo5ECqgrppL2FCH8PHsRga0=442
summary: There are 3 kinds of “going viral”, but only 1 helps your business (2 minute read) Most viral content falls into empathy or debate, creating visibility without durable value or consistent conversion. The most profitable form is resource virality, where posts deliver tactical utility that audiences actively save and reuse. These posts grow more slowly but establish authority and long-term distribution. Success depends on clarity and designing content explicitly for future reference or shares.

title: We Fixed A 6-Year-Old JavaScript Memory Leak
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-29, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.debugbear.com%2Fblog%2Fjavascript-memory-leak%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c09a85cd6-32f217b1-61bb-4cfb-af76-7432261123e0-000000/yHARvLHRDQ6Z47aGryQqa3yN-AgwKIpccEPrkPK5J4g=442

title: The 80% Problem in Agentic Coding
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-29, Reading time: 19 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Faddyo.substack.com%2Fp%2Fthe-80-problem-in-agentic-coding%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c09a85cd6-32f217b1-61bb-4cfb-af76-7432261123e0-000000/wiKRpjl3PqrXtSymdapM2BtTg6qqz8P99qthG4WRCao=442
summary: The 80% Problem in Agentic Coding (19 minute read) Many engineers now use AI agents to write 80-100% of their code, transforming their role from direct implementers to orchestrators. This adoption has introduced new problems, such as conceptual AI errors, comprehension debt within codebases, and a productivity paradox where review times balloon. Engineers need to shift to a declarative approach, focusing on problem definition and architectural oversight.

title: Don't solve problems that don't exist
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-29, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fread.first1000.co%2Fp%2Fdont-solve-problems-that-dont-exist%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c09a85cd6-32f217b1-61bb-4cfb-af76-7432261123e0-000000/WiA-E6EMvIQy__gS5HuVvuZ1DpLxfv3BfNikHLRvkic=442
summary: Don't solve problems that don't exist (8 minute read) People frequently waste time solving problems that don't exist, driven by procrastination, unclear next steps, and a subconscious avoidance of discomfort. title: World Models
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-29, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fankitmaloo.com%2Fworld-models%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019c0a221193-af6acc78-3797-4ee0-9578-69f1e1aa4238-000000/rty6DE1k_UcZjpD8kXZm1HUpXH34A80DGfb2--UPqXc=442
summary: World Models (15 minute read) The AI industry is turning its focus to world models, models that predict the next state observations. These models aim to understand the causal laws of an environment like a video game, codebase, or market. Companies have been working on similar models for decades under different names, but the bottleneck to the next step is now almost able to be overcome. The next AI era will require learning from the world directly through execution and outcomes.

title: Why most activation metrics don't predict who will stay
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-30, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.revenuecat.com%2Fblog%2Fgrowth%2Factivation-metrics%2F%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019c0ecc4a52-f768877c-f06c-4ff0-97bc-106cda060e86-000000/AtaSH51qDan-NTPLUrzQZbE2bw-yrvrB0QzqeiFgoAM=442
summary: Why most activation metrics don't predict who will stay (11 minute read) Most activation metrics fail because they track steps or engagement, not whether users reach meaningful value. Signups, onboarding, or session length can look good while users drop off or never convert. True activation happens when users experience early and sustained value. Measuring first value and core value moments shows who is likely to stay. Focus on behaviors that drive long-term subscribers.

title: Deep dive into Turso, the "SQLite rewrite in Rust"
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-30, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fkerkour.com%2Fturso-sqlite%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c0ecf9486-291c6964-facc-46f3-82cc-945f66787227-000000/ywtsBTjFCoXEkI55AjgT8C_cWP8c8oIjnXXTipwW5aI=442
summary: Deep dive into Turso, the "SQLite rewrite in Rust" (7 minute read) Turso is a database engine written in Rust. Designed as a rewrite of SQLite, it resolves SQLite's issues, such as a closed test suite, lack of concurrent writes, and C's memory management problems, by having built-in encryption, MVCC support, and the safety benefits of Rust. Unlike SQLite, Turso has the ability to scale from an in-process embedded database to a networked, cloud-hosted solution.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-30, Reading time: 22 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.mikeswanson.com%2Fbackseat-software%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c0ecf9486-291c6964-facc-46f3-82cc-945f66787227-000000/OeK6-veOuxDVPfBcHWdj3-HnqrFvxObZHQ__2phy5kU=442
summary: Backseat Software (22 minute read) Modern software has devolved into "backseat software" that constantly interrupts and tries to manage user behavior. This evolution began with the internet enabling updates and telemetry, gradually escalating as companies prioritized optimizing engagement metrics through measurement, A/B testing, and pervasive nudges. The ideal alternative to this is quiet that respects user attention and treats communication as opt-in.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-30, Reading time: 22 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.ravi-mehta.com%2Fp%2Fbuilding-ai-products-lessons-from%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019c0f045dd3-2611ee66-0bc3-42f7-8116-c48577dbf11f-000000/RCIpjx_sM2OEOWQr6XCgQcXjVyfSdB-2t9S5VOBfAl0=442
summary: Building AI products: Lessons from Productboard Spark (22 minute read) The fundamentals of product management haven't changed. Building AI products is still about solving real problems for real people. Start by matching customer pain to tech capabilities, build prototypes fast, measure quality rigorously, and evolve your team as you scale. The teams that ship great AI products will be the ones that learned fastest from what didn't work.

title: The Fundability Trap
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-30, Reading time: 17 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Finsights.euclid.vc%2Fp%2Fthe-fundability-trap%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019c0f045dd3-2611ee66-0bc3-42f7-8116-c48577dbf11f-000000/pfCDhQhdJQa9syeXH6QdWavPkpNSAMd2rXtlbaAUidI=442
summary: The Fundability Trap (17 minute read) Fundability is the measure of how well a startup fits with the current venture consensus. Investability is a measure of potential outcome and financial return. VCs that conflate the two or don't recognize the difference risk building an entire ecosystem that rewards fundability. Chasing fundability over investability has never been a reliable path to outlier outcomes and fund returns.

title: Trust minimized transaction simulation using state proofs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-30, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fethresear.ch%2Ft%2Ftrust-minimized-transaction-simulation-using-state-proofs%2F23857%23post_2%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019c0f16ebea-235538ea-67bb-44cc-952c-f17bf049dc55-000000/dr_qYgZYCxvQrr-673wtNyb_0qIuezlV3qL21NLWOkg=442
summary: Trust minimized transaction simulation using state proofs (2 minute read) Wallet simulations currently depend on vulnerable RPC providers for state data. Deploying Merkle Patricia Trie proofs and multi-node consensus enables cryptographic prestate verification before execution. This trust-minimized architecture eliminates single points of failure, providing users with verifiable security when previewing transactions before signing.

summary: How I Structure My Data Pipelines: The Silver Layer (12 minute read) The Silver layer combines Medallion (Bronze-Silver-Gold) with Kimball dimensional modeling, serving as the core by organizing data into business-domain schemas with facts (granular events) and dimensions (attributes with surrogate keys), using intermediates for reusable transformations, and RLS/CLM access controls. This design ensures predictability, schema evolution, isolation of business logic in Silver, and composability.
